Award.AwardTitle: A Study for Improving Animal Welfare by Focusing on Scientific Publications on Research with Laboratory Animals that Include a Discussion of Pain Management Practice

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Divn Of Social and Economic Sciences

Award.AbstractNarration:
General Audience Summary

The project aims both to improve the life of laboratory animals, and to improve the data that comes from experimentation on them. To accomplish these aims, the investigator will analyze the reporting of pain management in research involving animal subjects. The results of this analysis will be used to recommend guidelines on improved data gathering and publication practices as integral components of responsible use of animal subjects and improved animal welfare. The results will also be incorporated into the investigator's teaching (of veterinarians, laboratory technicians, and scientists) and they will be presented in publications for lay audiences interested in science and in animal welfare.

Technical Summary

The investigator and his team will weave together two strands of concern, data quality and the ethical treatment of animals in animal research. They will review 250 publications using animal subjects and analyze their description of pain management. The resulting database will then serve as the basis for an analysis of the varied approaches to pain management with the goal of illuminating some of the most significant motivating factors in the researchers reports (and underreports) of pain management. The goal of this project is to expand the conversation regarding the role of pain management in animal research. The formal analysis of published research with a focus on the description of pain management practice will provide new insight to this fundamental component of all animal research.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Data reproducibility and laboratory animal pain management are both important for quality science, and also for animal welfare. The welfare implications for animals who undergo surgeries in the laboratory are obvious: they suffer if they do not receive the best possible pain medications at the correct dose and interval. Along with the welfare concerns, numerous studies have shown that the anesthetics and analgesic pain medications that scientists use wtih their laboratory animals can affect the data those animals generate. Analgesics and anesthetics can affect behavior, immune function, cancer biology and many other bioogical outcomes. Untreated animal pain can also similarly affect behavior, immune function, cancer biology, etc. For decades, American animal welfare law has recognized scientists' concern that pain medications may affect research outcomes, and have carved out a special reporting mechanism to track how many animals (of the limited number of species covered by the Animal Welfare Act) are in this situation every year. 

Given the dual welfare and data-quality impact of pain management decisions, we would expect that most animal research reports should include this information in detail in their materials and methods. Indeed, scientists might expect this too, as they rely on published literature as their guide for how to conduct experiments. Likewise, if they feel a need to conduct painful procedures and to withold pain medications, they and their veterinarian and ethics/animal care and use committee (IACUC) similarly rely on this literature in deciding how well justified unalleviated pain is for a given set of experiments.

In this project, we reviewed published research papers, and the papers they cite, for completeness of reporting on animal pain management for animals who undergo surgery. While nearly 85% made some mention that animals were anesthetized for surgery, roughly 75% of the papers we scored gave no information on post-surgical pain medications. It is impossible to know if animals received such medications and if they did, which drugs they received. Certainly no articles explicitly stated that they witheld pain medication, though this is importnat information for others planning similar lines of research. We found no pattern that articles in high impact journals fared better or worse on this criterion, and no indication that journals who say they subscribed to published guidelines for reporting animal experiments had a higher rate of complete information. 

We raise the concern that non-reporting of pain management is too easily misinterpreted as non-use of analgesics, and that this creates and perpetuates a culture of analgesic under-use. The welfare implications --- when aniamls are denied pain medications in the mistaken belief that no one else using similar experimental models uses them --- are clear. But given the range of effects on data that untreated pain, or pain treated by a wide range of pain medications, can have, this under-reporting of pain management practices similarly creates unnecessary challenges to cross-laboratory data reproducibiltiy. Voluntary guidelines so far do not seem to be improving this situation. We argue that a stronger approach mgiht work, not necessarily requiring insitutions somehow to force scientists to include pain managment information, but perhaps including this as part of researcher training in animal laboratories.
